content:
ASIA-PAC

US & China are reportedly struggling to set a September meeting for trade talks, while it was also reported that China's Commerce Ministry lodged a case against the US at the WTO and reiterated its position that it is against US tariffs. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said he is encouraged by progress on Brexit and that chances of a deal are rising, while he added that the EU can see UK wants a deal and has a vision for future relationship. PM Johnson also reiterated his argument that getting a deal would be made impossible if MPs vote for a Brexit delay and that the UK is to leave on 31st October as he will not ask for a delay under any circumstances but believes UK will get a deal at the October EU summit. In other news, UK PM Johnson said Chancellor Javid will announce a spending round on Wednesday. (Newswires/Sky)

UK PM Johnson is expected to say if lawmakers vote for another Brexit delay on Tuesday, there will be a vote for a General Election on Wednesday with the view to conduct the vote on 14th October according to ITV’s Peston, while other reports also suggested that PM Johnson wants an election before the EU Council meeting scheduled for 17th-18th October. (Twitter/ITV/Sun)

A senior government source said that a vote by MPs on preventing a no-deal will essentially be a confidence vote in the government and that the logical extension of that argument is that if the government loses an election will follow, according to ITV’s Brand. Furthermore, a government source also stated it is wrong for MPs to strip control of Parliament from the government without the consent of the people, according to The Sun's political editor who sees this as a strong case of 'General Election talk'. (Twitter/ITV/Sun)

Legislation to stave off a no-deal Brexit would reportedly request a three-month A50 extension if no deal is reached by 19th October, while it was separately reported that Tory rebels believe they are confident of around 19 rebels with perhaps half a dozen on top of it which would mean defeat for government, which is fuelling some election rumours in Whitehall. (BBC/Twitter/Sky)

Cabinet ministers to be told draft legal text on Northern Ireland plan has been drawn up and ready to be introduced, although sources said the legal text is just the existing protocol with the relevant articles on the backstop crossed out. (Twitter/Sky)

EU will only make compromises on backstop if there is a majority in UK Parliament and EU leaders currently see PM Johnson doesn't have the numbers, according to BBC's Katya Adler. Furthermore, no new proposals have been put forward by PM Johnson and there is said to be a deep sense of mistrust in Johnson's Government. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar said alternative arrangements are better than nothing but he is prepared to veto alternative arrangements, while Varadkar is to meet UK PM Johnson next week and will listen to alternatives to the backstop although so far suggestions do not suffice. (Newswires/The Atlantic)

subject: US (EARLY) MARKETS WRAP: US rejects China request for tariff delay
content:
• REAR VIEW: US reject China request to delay tariffs; Europe PMIs still signal weakness, ramps pressure on ECB to act; more hawkish ECB talks; election talk grows in the UK; OPEC production seen rising.
  • AHEAD: RBA, Australian Retail Sales, Swiss CPI, Turkish CPI, UK Construction PMI, EZ PPI, US Manufacturing PMI, US ISM Manufacturing, US Construction Spending.

* MARKET WRAP: With US and Canadian players away for Labor Day, a mild risk-off tone to trade has engulfed markets. There was a collection of factors behind the cautious tone: although China’s Caixin PMI moved back into expansionary territory overnight, the internals (particularly new export orders) came in soft; it was a similar situation for the Eurozone manufacturing PMI, and most European countries manufacturing indices are still in contraction. UK PMI was grim, with no signs of Brexit stockpiling to support the economy in Q3. Gold and oil have largely taken their cues overarching sentiment, though the latter is also being pressured by signs of increasing crude supply, and a strengthening USD. Cash Treasuries were closed, and futures are slightly higher. In Fx, the USD is up; overnight, a stronger than expected yuan fix helped stabilised FX sentiment; expectations of ECB easing have weighed on EUR. GBP is under pressure amid Brexit news flow. After Europe left, US/China trade news weighed on risk assets, calling into question whether the two sides will meet in September for face-to-face talks. In a reaction, ES futures, which had been trading around the 2920 area, fell to sub-2900, though have recovered around the figure. Ahead of the APAC session, there will be attention on comments from UK PM Johnson at 1800 BST.

* CHINA: US officials reportedly rejected China’s request to delay the implementation of the 1st September tariffs, and the two sides are struggling to set a September meeting date for trade talks. In a reaction, risk assets saw downside.

* FX WRAP: USD is firmer on Labor Day, taking its cue from a weakening yuan and EUR; although the PBOC fixed USDCNY stronger than models had suggested, adding ballast to EMFX, both onshore and offshore yuans are weaker – and found further weakness on negative trade headlines after the European close. EUR: Manufacturing PMIs improved slightly on the month, but are still mostly remain in contraction, ramping up pressure on the ECB to loosen policy on 12th September; the pricing for a 20bps rate cut is not over 50%, keeping EUR on the defensive; narrowing bund/BTP differentials have had little impact of late, but desks will be watching the outcome of the 5SM members poll on whether it approves a coalition with the PD. That Bund/BTP that spread has narrowed to around 165bps this week, from over 200bps a week earlier. GBP trades heavy on speculation UK PM Johnson is gearing up to call General Elections, while anti-Brexit MPs scheme. Havens JPY and CHF are up; with the latter, amid increasing speculation about the aggressive easing package the ECB will unleash next week, some are warning that EURCHF downside could force the SNB’s hand ahead of the ECB’s meeting, and indeed its own; data on Monday showed record sight deposits pared back in the weak, suggesting a less active SNB in currency markets. Elsewhere, XAU trades firm. EMFX is mixed. ARS reportedly fell to record lows in black market trade, newswires reported, after the country imposed capital controls – those controls were also cited by some as a reason why the BRL was under pressure; the Real could not build on manufacturing PMI rising to the highest since March, while a survey showed inflation expectations fell to fresh lows, the BCB’s survey economists said, giving more scope for the central bank to loosen policy. TRY is performing well in EMFX after firmer than expected GDP and PMI data. ZAR is flat.

* ECB: Hawkish remarks from ECB’s Lautenschlager, and Holzmann (who replaces Nowotny), ahead of the central bank’s 12th September confab. The former, when asked about the need for a package of stimulus measures, echoed recent remarks from ECB's Knot, saying it is much too early for a huge package; she is still convinced that the APP is a measure of last resort, only to be used if the risk of deflation is present, and added that rate cuts would be something to think about before you consider non-standard measure like APP. Holzmann, who is showing his hawkish feathers early on in his tenure, on the weekend said he’d “probably express more criticism toward proposals for further monetary deepening.”

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson is mulling early elections if pro-EU lawmakers who want to block a no-deal Brexit defeat the government in a confidence this week, BBC reported; UK state news also said "live discussions" were happening in Downing Street to ask Parliament to approve a snap poll - something which could happen as soon as Wednesday, though no decision has been made. The move seems designed to bring Tory rebels on side (around 19 of them, reports suggest), with the argument that if they do not back the government in parliament (either by voting against the government in a confidence motion, or backing legislation that ties the government's hands), then they face the prospect of campaigning for their jobs. The immediate question is when any election would take place - before the EU meeting on 17-18th August? After that meeting, allowing the EU to either jawbone or make an offer to force a UK extension? Before Brexit on 31st October (giving a new government scope to extend Article 50)? Or after the Brexit date, after which the UK will already have left the EU. Johnson is holding an emergency meeting with Cabinet members in the afternoon, before the PM hosts Conservative lawmakers at a reception at Downing Street. Meanwhile, Brexit rebels are set to take control of parliamentary affairs on Wednesday, when they will try to force through legislation that calls for a three month A50 extension (to 31/Jan/2020) if PM Johnson has not secured an exit deal with the EU on 19th October (a day after the EU summit); Downing Street has intimated that the legislation will be a de facto confidence vote on the government, and there is speculation that an election would be called if the government does not come out on top this week.

* CRUDE: Oil was pressured by overall risk sentiment, as well as signs of more crude coming to the market. Russian crude oil production rose to 11.29mln BPD in August (vs July’s 11.15mln BPD), while loadings of Russia's ESPO crude from Kozimo is set at a monthly record for October at 3.12mln tones; separately, Russia Energy Minister Novak says he discussed global oil market cooperation with his Iranian counterpart; Iraq’s August crude oil exports rose to 3.603mln BPD (vs 3.566mln BPD in July); Equinor has won permission to start its Sverdrup oilfield in the fall. Additionally, Bloomberg News’ monthly crude poll sees OPEC output rising in the latest month, with analysts estimating August oil production at 29.61mln BPD (+80k BPD vs July), the first increase since the new round of the oil supply curb deal came into effect at the beginning of the year; Nigeria and Saudi are set to lead the output gains, collectively adding 200k BPD to the market, the survey suggested; the report also noted how Russia has shown signs of backsliding on its commitments. 

* GEOPOLITICS: Hong Kong leader Lam says she would 'quit' if she could, fears her ability to resolve crisis now 'very limited', Reuters reported. Separately, Hong Kong police were reportedly firing tear gas at protestors in the Mong Kok region. Elsewhere, Iran vowed to scale back its commitments under the 2015 nuclear deal if Europe failed to shield Tehran's economy from US sanctions, foreign minister Zarif said.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Sterling woes as UK general election chatter grows
content:
GBP

Sterling sunk on Monday, with newswires citing the familiar theme of Brexit concerns as no deal by legal default creeps one day closer, although weaker than expected Manufacturing PMI data, which highlighted the impact Brexit is having on the economy, doing little to help. The currency staged a fleeting rebound as rumours began to circulate that a UK election could be called as early as this week, should the UK PM Johnson lose a vote forcing him ask for another Brextension (if he fails to broker a revamped deal). However, gains were quickly reversed, as participants digested the potential implications of an election; with the Conservative Party currently polling well ahead of the opposition and disunity in the opposition rendering the prospect of a Labour-Lib Dem coalition unlikely, an election could actually hand Johnson a larger majority. Right now, Cable is consolidating just above 1.2050; in terms of key levels, technicians will be eyeing the YTD low at 1.2015 and questioning whether the currency pair could see a similar price action to that seen in EURUSD last Friday, where the Single currency crashed below YTD lows and then the psychological 1.10 level vs the buck.

USD/EUR/CNY/JPY/CHF

DXY continued its crawl higher, making fresh YTD highs above the 99 handle despite a lack of North American players in the market (due to holidays in the region); weakness amongst rival’s EUR and CNY continuing to lend support. EURUSD could not poke its head back above 1.10, and extended on last Friday’s decline after PMI data failed to provide much in the way of hope that Eurozone manufacturing might be about to rebound, seemingly upping the pressure on the ECB to act next week (market implied probability of a 20bps cut at next week’s ECB meeting has now extended above 60%). Meanwhile, CNY started the week on the back foot, with fresh US & Chinese tariffs on each other’s imports going into effect over the weekend and mixed signals from manufacturing PMI data doing little to help. Havens, JPY and CHF, were uneventful, with the former fairly flat around 106.30 and the latter slightly weaker above 0.99 vs the buck.

AUD/NZD/SEK/NOK/CAD

Some divergence in the Aussie and Kiwi saw AUDNZD down towards 1.0650 from 1.0685; the Aussie was initially weaker on the back of mixed Chinese PMIs overnight and a shock drop in Q2 Australian business inventories while the Kiwi, albiet also lower vs the buck in early trade, fared better on improved NZ Q2 terms of trade. However, the two staged somewhat of a comeback towards the end of European trading hours, AUDUSD and NZDUSD rebounding to 0.6730 and 0.6315 respectively from 0.6710 and 0.6290 lows. Similarly, USDCAD also rebounded off highs at 1.3360, falling back to overnight lows around 1.3310, despite an uneventful crude complex. The Scandis are both firmer on decent PMI data, most notably from Norway where the headline figure rebounded back above 50.0. AUD and SEK traders will now look ahead to RBA and Riksbank rate decisions on Tuesday and Thursday respectively.

EMFX

Broadly weaker amid dollar strength. However, TRY and ARS bucked the trend, with good PMI and better than expected GDP data supportive of the former, and the latter firming below the 60.00 handle with the announcement of capital controls seemingly halting the slide (for now).

RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Dollar dominates as EUR slips on US Labour Day - 2nd September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

Major European indices are firmer [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%], as markets initially struggled for clear direction, after the downbeat Asia-Pac session as the additional US levy on Chinese goods and China’s retaliatory tariffs came into effect alongside today’s US market holiday; before taking a positive line. Notably, the FTSE 100 (+1.5%) is outperforming its peers, as exporters benefit from the subdued Sterling due to the ongoing Brexit narrative over PM Johnson’s prorogation and the increasing likelihood of a no-deal outcome, whilst downbeat UK manufacturing PMI further weighed on the currency. Sectors opened the session all in the green but have since deteriorated somewhat to a mixed performance. In terms of individual movers, AstraZeneca (+3.3%) are topping the FTSE 100 after positive Phase III trial results; just below the Co. on the Stoxx 600 this morning is Adecco (+2.2%) after being upgraded to outperform from neutral at Credit Suisse. At the other end of the spectrum, Thyssenkrupp (-0.8%) shares are lower ahead of Wednesday’s DAX 30 reshuffle, during which the Co. are expected to be demoted from the index and German listed MTU Aero Engines (+2.1%) is seen as a strong contender for the empty spot.

FX

GBP - Sterling was already looking shaky in the run up to the UK manufacturing PMI amidst reports of RHS demand in Eur/Gbp for the 9.00 am fix (perhaps residual or belated month end orders), with Cable slipping towards and just through 1.2100 amidst heightened jitters ahead of tomorrow’s new and potentially truncated Parliament term. However, the Pound briefly regrouped even though the headline print was worse than forecast and sub-components were bleak before succumbing to more selling pressure as Tory rebels continued their condemnation of PM Johnson’s move to suspend the upcoming session in an attempt to head off a no deal Brexit motion. On that note, latest reports suggest that a cross-party group will launch a bill aimed at blocking no deal within hours, and Cable is hovering just above 1.2075 awaiting further developments/news, while Eur/Gbp is holding near the top of a circa 0.9025-85 range. From a chart perspective, 1.2065 is next on the downside for Cable (August 20 low) ahead of 1.2015 (2019 base) and hefty option/barrier interest at the 1.2000 strike

USD - The Dollar is firmer almost across the board, as the DXY inches a bit further above the 99.000 handle to a marginal new ytd peak (99.109) and closer to the next line of chart resistance (99.262) in wake of additional/higher US tariffs on around 1/3 of the remaining Usd300 bn Chinese goods and Usd75 bn US exports to China in return. However, the Greenback is also gaining at the expense of rival currencies that continue to weaken of their own accord, as noted above.

EUR/CHF/CAD/AUD/NZD/JPY - The single currency derived some indirect support via the aforementioned Sterling cross activity through the run of Eurozone manufacturing PMIs, but Eur/Usd has subsequently retreated from a circa 1.1000 recovery high to print a fresh, albeit slender, yearly low at 1.0958, not far from supposed expiries at 1.0950, but away from a hefty 1.8 bn rolling off at the big figure. Meanwhile, the Franc is closer to the base of a 0.9918-0.9890 band, but outperforming vs the Euro within 1.0866-99 parameters and the Loonie has lost impetus between 1.3310-1.3340 vs its US counterpart. Elsewhere, the Aussie is meandering from 0.6715 to 0.6735 on the back of mixed Chinese PMIs overnight and a shock drop in Q2 Australian business inventories vs the Kiwi that is just keeping its head above 0.6300 following improved NZ Q2 terms of trade that has nudged Anz/Nzd down towards 1.0650 from 1.0685. The Yen has drifted towards 106.40 from just over 106.00 at one stage with Japanese PM Abe due to announce a cabinet reshuffle next week and Q2 Capex a bit better than expected.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi Crowns have both been boosted by encouraging manufacturing PMIs, and especially from Norway where the headline rebounded above 50.0 again, with Eur/Sek eyeing 10.7500 and Eur/Nok sub-10.0000.

EM - The Turkish Lira has also rebounded from worst levels with the aid of a better manufacturing PMI, but also as Q2 GDP data revealed less contraction. Usd/Try has tested 5.8000 bids/support vs a high just a few pips shy of 5.8400, but Usd/Ars may see more upside if capital controls fail to stop the rot.

FIXED INCOME

UK bonds remain well ahead of core contemporaries and roughly on a par with Italian BTPs, but lost momentum within single digits of their 134.91 Dec19 futures peak posted last Thursday after follow-through buying in wake of a deeper sub-50 manufacturing PMI. However, Gilts and Short Sterling appear more focused on events behind the scenes in Whitehall and moves to enact legal challenges to a no deal Brexit as early as Tuesday if not sooner. Meanwhile, Bunds and US Treasuries are lagging in thinner Labour Day trading conditions amidst a rebound in broad risk sentiment, albeit fragile and flaky, with the curves steeper. Note, the 10 year German benchmark recently retreated to 178.60, through last Friday’s 178.63 intraday base, but respecting the August 29 session trough (178.57) for now at least.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are slightly softer, with prices just above the 55/bbl and 59/bbl levels with little by way of specific catalysts thus far, although gains in the complex are somewhat capped by the latest imposition of US and China tariffs in which China slapped a 5% levy on US crude oil exports. Despite demand woes outweighing supply concerns, it is worth keeping an eye on Hurricane Dorian which, according to the NHC’s latest update, is drifting westward with life-threatening storm surges and dangerous hurricane-force winds expected along the Florida east coast through mid-week. As it stands, production in the Gulf of Mexico has not been affected. On the geopolitical front, UK is said to be considering sending drones to near the Gulf of Oman amid its crisis with Iran, which follows comments from the UK’s Royal Navy Captain who stated that its warship has faced 115 confrontations with the IRGC since the start of July. Elsewhere, gold prices are marginally firmer, in-spite of the weaker Buck, albeit the yellow metal remains above the USD 1500/oz handle. Copper prices are lacklustre today as trade woes weighed on the red metal with little impetus derived from mixed China PMIs. Meanwhile, China’s iron ore futures rose around 6% at a point to a two-week high with desks citing robust short-term demand with Beijing rolling out more support measures to the Chinese economy. Finally, nickel prices gained in excess of 8% after the Indonesian Finance Ministry said nickel ore export ban will take effect as of January 1st 2020 (as touted), and new mineral ore export ban is only to be implemented for all Nickel Ore grades.

subject: Fixed Income: Gilts fade after attempting to revisit end of August contract high
content: UK bonds remain well ahead of core contemporaries and roughly on a par with Italian BTPs, but lost momentum within single digits of their 134.91 Dec19 futures peak posted last Thursday after follow-through buying in wake of a deeper sub-50 manufacturing PMI. However, Gilts and Short Sterling appear more focused on events behind the scenes in Whitehall and moves to enact legal challenges to a no deal Brexit as early as Tuesday if not sooner. Meanwhile, Bunds and US Treasuries are lagging in thinner Labour Day trading conditions amidst a rebound in broad risk sentiment, albeit fragile and flaky, with the curves steeper. Note, the 10 year German benchmark recently retreated to 178.60, through last Friday’s 178.63 intraday base, but respecting the August 29 session trough (178.57) for now at least.

FX Morning Colour: Pound precarious pre and post-PMI
content:
GBP

Sterling was already looking shaky in the run up to the UK manufacturing PMI amidst reports of RHS demand in Eur/Gbp for the 9.00 am fix (perhaps residual or belated month end orders), with Cable slipping towards and just through 1.2100 amidst heightened jitters ahead of tomorrow’s new and potentially truncated Parliament term. However, the Pound briefly regrouped even though the headline print was worse than forecast and sub-components were bleak before succumbing to more selling pressure as Tory rebels continued their condemnation of PM Johnson’s move to suspend the upcoming session in an attempt to head off a no deal Brexit motion. On that note, latest reports suggest that a cross-party group will launch a bill aimed at blocking no deal within hours, and Cable is hovering just above 1.2075 awaiting further developments/news, while Eur/Gbp is holding near the top of a circa 0.9025-85 range. From a chart perspective, 1.2065 is next on the downside for Cable (August 20 low) ahead of 1.2015 (2019 base) and hefty option/barrier interest at the 1.2000 strike 

USD 

The Dollar is firmer almost across the board, as the DXY inches a bit further above the 99.000 handle to a marginal new ytd peak (99.109) and closer to the next line of chart resistance (99.262) in wake of additional/higher US tariffs on around 1/3 of the remaining Usd300 bn Chinese goods and Usd75 bn US exports to China in return. However, the Greenback is also gaining at the expense of rival currencies that continue to weaken of their own accord, as noted above.

EUR/CHF/CAD/AUD/NZD/JPY

The single currency derived some indirect support via the aforementioned Sterling cross activity through the run of Eurozone manufacturing PMIs, but Eur/Usd has subsequently retreated from a circa 1.1000 recovery high to print a fresh, albeit slender, yearly low at 1.0958, not far from supposed expiries at 1.0950, but away from a hefty 1.8 bn rolling off at the big figure. Meanwhile, the Franc is closer to the base of a 0.9918-0.9890 band, but outperforming vs the Euro within 1.0866-99 parameters and the Loonie has lost impetus between 1.3310-1.3340 vs its US counterpart. Elsewhere, the Aussie is meandering from 0.6715 to 0.6735 on the back of mixed Chinese PMIs overnight and a shock drop in Q2 Australian business inventories vs the Kiwi that is just keeping its head above 0.6300 following improved NZ Q2 terms of trade that has nudged Anz/Nzd down towards 1.0650 from 1.0685. The Yen has drifted towards 106.40 from just over 106.00 at one stage with Japanese PM Abe due to announce a cabinet reshuffle next week and Q2 Capex a bit better than expected.

SEK/NOK

The Scandi Crowns have both been boosted by encouraging manufacturing PMIs, and especially from Norway where the headline rebounded above 50.0 again, with Eur/Sek eyeing 10.7500 and Eur/Nok sub-10.0000.

EM

The Turkish Lira has also rebounded from worst levels with the aid of a better manufacturing PMI, but also as Q2 GDP data revealed less contraction. Usd/Try has tested 5.8000 bids/support vs a high just a few pips shy of 5.8400, but Usd/Ars may see more upside if capital controls fail to stop the rot.

subject: Italy's 5-Star Movement members will take part in an online vote between 08:00-18:00 local time (07:00-17:00 BST) on Tuesday on whether the party should form a government with the Democratic Party (PD).
analysis_details:
• The 5SM usually puts key strategic decisions to an online vote of its members. 
  • Such a move could wreck the potential deal, given that the populist party’s leadership is split between those who favour a coalition with 5SM and those who believe it will hamper voter support. 
  • Deputy PM Di Maio said the 5-Star leadership will support a new government only if party members approve it through an online vote planned by this week.

subject: UK Rebel MP’s are reportedly to attempt to rush through legislation to block a no-deal Brexit through Parliament in just a few hours, which would make it difficult for MPs to consider tabling amendments., BuzzFeed News
content:
• The Draft motion, which contains 19 clauses and could change substantially by the time it is tabled, outlines the plan to move a motion at an emergency debate on Tuesday, If passed, it would allow MPs opposed to no-deal to seize control of the House of Commons from the government and then pass legislation in the Commons within hours. After which, rebel MP’s would table legislation which would require PM Johnson to seek an extension from the EU if a deal has not been agreed by a undecided date in October
  • Rebel MPs are led by Oliver Letwin, Dominic Grieve and Keir Starmer
  • Rebels have been divided on whether to attempt to pass the motion and legislation in one day on Tuesday, or over two days on Tuesday and Wednesday
  • Source said some MPs want to get the bill through Parliament over one day in order to hamper government efforts to block the legislation. Another source said it was likely to clear Parliament on Wednesday
  • Rebel source close to those working on the plan stated that simple bills can go through all Commons stages in a single day, with Starmer having described the proposal as a ‘Simple Plan’

HSBC on the ECB's 12th September policy announcement
content:
• A 20bps cut to the deposit rate to take it to -60bps. 20bps will be required if 'over delivery' is an aim of the Governing Council. However, exceeding market expectations could be a difficult task for policymakers.
  • Implementation of a tiered rate system. It will be hard to convince all GC members, however, HSBC believe that a Swiss-style system (i.e. banks no longer have to pay the negative deposit rate on some of their excess reserves) will be implemented.
  • Asset purchases to begin in Jan 2020 for 12  months, at EUR 30bln per month. Issue limit likely to be raised from 33% to 50% in order to achieve credibility. 
  • Forward guidance to be updated to something like rates to remain "“at present levels or lower for an extended  period of time, and well past the horizon of the net asset purchases”.
  • Concerns about a protracted slowdown in growth should see policymakers cut 2019 and 2020 growth forecasts with 2021 unchanged. 
  • Softer growth prospects and a 15% fall in oil prices likely to see 2019 and 2020 inflation forecasts lowered by 0.2pp

subject: Bunds: still keeping tabs on the 179.00 handle
content: The 10 year German benchmark remains relatively rangebound and eyeing Eurozone manufacturing PMIs for some early September impetus ahead of a trio of ECB speakers that will be monitored intently given next week’s policy meeting and a run of hawkish comments of late. However, after particularly aggressive rhetoric from new GC member Holzmann who believes a hike would be more apt than a cut if there is any need to tweak rates, today’s line-up offers a relatively balanced outlook via Lautenschlaeger, de Guindos and Couere. Note, volumes are typically light due to the US Labour Day holiday.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

2nd September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly negatively after the latest round of tariffs in the US-China trade war took effect and as the region digested mixed Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were lower with early underperformance seen in Australia’s energy sector following the recent pullback for oil prices and with Telecoms weighed after Telstra reduced its FY EBITDA guidance, while the Japanese benchmark was also downbeat but off its lows as price action was determined by a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.1%) diverged with outperformance in the mainland despite the latest round of tariffs taking effect, as China’s state council pledged more support for the economy and Caixin Manufacturing PMI topped estimates with its first expansion in 3 months, to provide some much-needed reprieve after the miss on China’s Official Manufacturing PMI data over the weekend. Conversely, the Hang Seng lagged following further clashes between protesters and police over the weekend and as participants reacted to a slump in Retail Sales.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 2nd August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly negatively after the 15% US tariffs on about USD 112bln of Chinese goods went into effect
  • UK PM Johnson reportedly issued an ultimatum to Tory rebels that they would be expelled from the party if they joined forces with Labour leader Corbyn to halt a no-deal Brexit
  • In FX, the DXY was slightly softer, USD/JPY initially slipped to below 106.00 but then gradually recovered
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ & UK Manufacturing PMIs, ECB’s Mersch, Lautenschlager, de Guindos & Coeure and US Labor Day Holiday

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly negatively after the latest round of tariffs in the US-China trade war took effect and as the region digested mixed Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were lower with early underperformance seen in Australia’s energy sector following the recent pullback for oil prices and with Telecoms weighed after Telstra reduced its FY EBITDA guidance, while the Japanese benchmark was also downbeat but off its lows as price action was determined by a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.1%) diverged with outperformance in the mainland despite the latest round of tariffs taking effect, as China’s state council pledged more support for the economy and Caixin Manufacturing PMI topped estimates with its first expansion in 3 months, to provide some much-needed reprieve after the miss on China’s Official Manufacturing PMI data over the weekend. Conversely, the Hang Seng lagged following further clashes between protesters and police over the weekend and as participants reacted to a slump in Retail Sales. Finally, 10yr JGBs declined despite the risk averse tone in Japan, with prices weakened after the BoJ lowered its purchase amounts of 10yr-25yr JGBs for today’s Rinban operation, while it also recently announced a reduction in its buying intentions in 5yr-10yr JGBs for the month.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0883 vs. Exp. 7.1057 (Prev. 7.0879)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Aug) 49.5 vs. Exp. 49.7 (Prev. 49.7). (Newswires) Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Aug) 53.8 vs. Exp. 53.6 (Prev. 53.7) Chinese Composite PMI (Aug) 53.0 (Prev. 53.1) Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Aug) 50.4 vs. Exp. 49.8 (Prev. 49.9); first expansion in 2 months.

The new 15% US tariffs on about USD 112bln of Chinese goods went into effect, while China’s Customs Tariff Commission of the State Council also confirmed the first round of tariff increases on USD 75bln of US goods. (Newswires)

China’s State Council issued a statement pledging more support and stated that it attached great importance to the development of infrastructure, high-tech, traditional industrial transformation, social services and new growth regions, while China will encourage banks to use more innovative tools to replenish capital through multiple channels. (Newswires)

Hong Kong protests clashed again with police over the weekend which resulted to a disruption of flights in Hong Kong International Airport and a third of stations were said to have been damaged during the protests. In related news, China announced it is to conduct a press conference regarding the Hong Kong situation on Tuesday at 1115 local time (0415BST/2215CDT). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reportedly issued ultimatum to former Chancellor Hammond and other Tory rebels that they would be expelled from the party if they join forces with Labour leader Corbyn to halt a no-deal Brexit. In other news, PM Johnson reportedly cancelled on what was said set to be a showdown meeting with Tory rebels including former justice secretary Gauke due to a diary clash. (Telegraph/Sky)

Labour Party Brexit spokesperson said MPs will attempt to pass a law this week to block a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

UK Cabinet Minister Gove suggested that the government could ignore any new law Tory rebels pass to thwart a no-deal Brexit. (CityAM)

UK Tory Brexiteers could reportedly mount a challenge to House Speaker Bercow over claims that he is biased towards Remainers. (Times)

EU Council President Tusk that the main problem with Brexit is the internal situation in Britain, while there were separate comments from EU Chief Brexit negotiator Barnier that he is not optimistic about averting a no-deal scenario, (Telegraph/Newswires)

ECB’s Rehn (Dove) stated that it is important to maintain strong monetary stimulus and that the situation called for an effective policy package. (Newswires)

ECB’s Holzmann (Hawk) stated he is worried about further additional stimulus to the EU and lowering the deposit rate, while he suggested that if there is an adjustment in rates, it should be a hike not a cut. (Newswires) Note, Holzmann has replaced Ewald Nowotny as head of the Austrian Central Bank

German Chancellor Merkel's CDU/CSU coalition retains control in Saxony and Brandenburg regional elections although lost seats to the far-right which made significant gains in both. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Switzerland at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Norway at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was slightly softer as it continued to ease back from the 99.00 level and its strongest in more than a year amid a lack of North American participants due to Labor Day holidays and renewed criticism on the Fed by US President Trump, although its major counterparts failed to take advantage with EUR/USD dejected after a recent slip to below 1.1000. GBP/USD was also relatively uneventful as it bides its time ahead of the reopen of Parliament on Tuesday where pro-EU MPs will attempt to block a no-deal Brexit, although there were also reports the PM issued an ultimatum to the Tory rebels that they would be expelled from the party if they join forces with Labour leader Corbyn to halt a no-deal Brexit. Elsewhere, USD/JPY initially slipped to below 106.00 but then gradually recovered a majority of the losses and antipodeans were also indecisive with early weakness counterbalanced by a firmer than expected CNY reference rate setting and better than expected Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI data.

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures flat around the USD 55.00/bbl level as the mostly risk averse tone hampered efforts to recoup Friday’s losses, while the latest Baker Hughes rig count which showed oil drillers cut rigs for the 8th time in the past 9 weeks, also failed to spur the energy complex. Elsewhere, gold marginally benefitted from the slight pullback in USD and copper was lacklustre despite amid the predominantly risk averse tone and mixed Chinese PMI data.

Georgia governor orders mandatory evacuation of state's coast beginning midday on Monday ahead of hurricane Dorian. (Newswires)

Baker Hughes oil rig count -12 at 742, natgas unchanged at 162, total rigs -12 at 904. (Newswires)

US June crude production fell 33k BPD to 12.082mln BPD (Prev. 12.115mln bpd), according to EIA. (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

The previously seized Iranian tanker which that was known as Grace 1 was reportedly preparing to offload its oil to Syria-bound ships which reports noted could undermine European efforts to broker US-Iran talks. (WSJ)

UK Royal Navy captain noted that its warship has faced 115 confrontations with Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps in the Gulf since the start of July. (Times)

 

US

The T-Note traded sideways to end the week, with volumes notedly light ahead of the long weekend in the US. Strong data, namely US consumer spending, PCE, and Canadian GDP, did little to induce outflows ahead of a busy data schedule next week, and of course the panned step up of US-China tariffs; however, the largest drop in the forward-looking University of Michigan survey didn’t exactly rock the boat either. At settlement yields were slightly lower between 1-2bps with the curve itself slightly steeper. US T-note (U9) futures settled 3+ ticks higher at 131.01+.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks traded mostly lower after the latest round of US-China tariffs took effect and as the region digests mixed Chinese PMI data
content: Asia equity markets traded mostly negative after the latest round of tariffs in the US-China trade war took effect and as the region digested mixed Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were lower with early underperformance seen in Australia’s energy sector following the recent pullback for oil prices and with Telecoms weighed after Telstra reduced its FY EBITDA guidance, while the Japanese benchmark was also downbeat but off its lows as price action was determined by a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.1%) diverged with outperformance in the mainland despite the latest round of tariffs taking effect, as China’s state council pledged more support for the economy and Caixin Manufacturing PMI topped estimates with its first expansion in 3 months, to provide some much-needed reprieve after the miss on China’s Official Manufacturing PMI data over the weekend. Conversely, the Hang Seng lagged following further clashes between protesters and police over the weekend and as participants reacted to a slump in Retail Sales. Finally, 10yr JGBs declined despite the risk averse tone in Japan, with prices weakened after the BoJ lowered its purchase amounts of 10yr-25yr JGBs for today’s Rinban operation, while it also recently announced a reduction in its buying intentions in 5yr-10yr JGBs for the month.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade mostly lower after the latest round of US-China tariffs took effect and as the region digests mixed Chinese PMI data
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly negative after the latest round of tariffs in the US-China trade war took effect and as the region digests mixed Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (-0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) are lower with underperformance seen in Australia’s energy sector following the recent pullback for oil prices and with Telecoms weighed after Telstra reduced its FY EBITDA guidance, while the Japanese benchmark is also downbeat but off its lows as price action is driven by a choppy currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) diverged with outperformance in the mainland despite the latest round of tariffs taking effect, as China’s state council pledged more support for the economy and Caixin Manufacturing PMI topped estimates with its first expansion in 3 months, to provide some much-needed reprieve after the miss on China’s Official Manufacturing PMI data over the weekend. Conversely, the Hang Seng lags following further clashes between protesters and police over the weekend and as participants react to a slump in retail sales data.

In FX markets, the DXY is slightly softer as its eases back from the 99.00 level and from its strongest in more than a year amid a lack of North American participants due to Labor Day holidays and renewed criticism on the Fed by US President Trump, while its major counterparts have failed to take advantage with EUR/USD dejected after a recent slip to below 1.1000. GBP/USD is also relatively uneventful as it bides its time ahead of the reopen of Parliament on Tuesday where pro-EU MPs will attempt to block a no-deal Brexit, although there were also reports the PM issued an ultimatum to the Tory rebels that they would be expelled from the party if they join forces with Labour leader Corbyn to halt a no-deal Brexit. Elsewhere, USD/JPY initially slipped to below 106.00 but then gradually recovered the majority of the losses and antipodeans are also indecisive with early weakness counterbalanced by a firmer than expected CNY reference rate and better than expected Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs declined despite the risk averse tone in Japan, with prices weakened after the BoJ lowered its purchase amounts of 10yr-25yr JGBs for today’s Rinban operation, while it also recently announced a reduction in its buying intentions in 5yr-10yr JGBs for the month.
